upload.title: Import your Twitter/X archive to continue your journey
upload.action: Drop or select your files here
upload.description:
Three data formats are accepted:
- your original X archive if <1GB (in Zip format)
- following.js and follower.js files TOGETHER and unzipped,
- split versions of these files for large archives (following-part*.js + follower-part*.js)

upload.helpButton: Help with getting your Twitter/X archive
upload.loading-uploading: Stay on the page, import in progress

helpModal.title: How to get your Twitter/X archive?
helpModal.description: To get your Twitter/X archive, follow these steps:
steps: Log in to your Twitter/X account
Go to "More" in the left menu
Click on "Settings and Support" then "Settings and Privacy"
In "Your Account", select "Download an archive of your data"
Twitter/X will send you an email when your archive is ready to download
Once downloaded, you can import the .zip file here
helpModal.note: Note: Twitter/X archive preparation can take up to 24 hours.

firstSeen.title: Welcome!
firstSeen.description:
You are about to exercise your right to data portability from X to BlueSky and/or Mastodon while participating in a social networks research project. This will take 5 minutes.

OpenPortability will reference your digital identities and help you progressively recreate your community on BlueSky and/or Mastodon, without impacting your X account.

As more users register on OpenPortability, the links referenced on X will be recreated on BlueSky or Mastodon with their consent. Feel free to encourage your followers to do the same!

This "copy" of your social network may take several days.

By using OpenPortability, you agree that your data will be processed in accordance with {lien} and consent to the potential transfer of your data outside the European Union (e.g., BlueSky servers).

challenge.title: The Challenge
challenge.content: How to position 658,000 accounts in a 2D plane so that similar accounts are close together?

node2vec.title: Step 1: Node2Vec (Graph ‚Üí 64D)
node2vec.content: Node2Vec is a graph representation algorithm inspired by Word2Vec. The idea: treat 'random walks' in the graph as sentences, and nodes as words. Each node is represented by a 64-dimensional vector capturing its structural position in the graph.

umap.title: Step 2: UMAP (64D ‚Üí 2D)
umap.subtitle: Uniform Manifold Approximation and Projection
umap.content: UMAP preserves both global AND local graph structure. Faster than t-SNE (essential for 658k points), deterministic results (scientific reproducibility), better distance preservation (clusters remain coherent).
umap.howItWorks: UMAP builds a topological graph in 64D space, then optimizes it in 2D by: preserving close neighborhoods (local structure), respecting global topology (manifold learning), minimizing cross-entropy between the two representations.

result.title: Final Result
result.content: Accounts that frequently interact naturally end up close in the 2D visual space, while preserving the global community structure.

summary.title: Summary
points: Node2Vec captures 'who is connected to whom'
UMAP projects this information into 2D so your eye can interpret it
The 64 intermediate dimensions capture nuances that 2D alone could not

communities.title: Community Detection Methods
communities.subtitle: Identifying thematic structures using a hybrid algorithm + semantic approach

step1.title: Step 1 - Structural Detection
step1.content: We use K-Means with k=50 applied directly to the 64-dimensional embedding vectors produced by node2vec.
step1.why: The embeddings already capture the graph structure (proximity = similarity). K-Means identifies clusters in the Euclidean space of embeddings. k=50 initial clusters allow fine granularity, later aggregated into 10 meta-communities for interpretability.
step1.advantages: Spatial coherence: clusters are visually contiguous. Flexibility: easy adjustment of cluster count.

step2.title: Step 2 - Semantic Annotation
step2.content: Extraction from a dictionary of verified accounts with twitter_id + descriptions. For each detected community: retrieval of verified account descriptions, cleaning (stop words removal), TF-IDF extraction of dominant keywords, aggregation of 50 clusters into 10 thematic meta-communities, manual labeling based on recurring terms.

privacy_policy.title: Data Protection Information Notice
privacy_policy.subtitle: Complex Systems Institute Paris Ile de France | January 2025
privacy_policy.content:
CNRS ISC PIF

Data protection information notice for scientific research Project Open Portability

Social networks, particularly Twitter (now X), have from the beginning been privileged objects of research, especially in the field of computational social sciences.

A historic transition is underway in the social network landscape. The centralized model, embodied by X (formerly Twitter), is experiencing a massive exodus of users to alternative platforms like BlueSky and Mastodon. Several million accounts have migrated in just a few weeks, marking a major shift towards decentralized and open networks.

This transition is a major social, economic, and technological phenomenon that may modify the global digital space, particularly in Europe, and could allow Europe to regain some digital sovereignty.

I. Project and Processing Description

The research objectives are as follows: analyze the difference between open and closed micro-blogging digital environments from the perspective of social dynamics and online debates. Study as a case study the ongoing migration between X and spaces based on open protocols AT Protocol and Activity Pub, and study the appropriation of decentralized digital spaces over time (5-year horizon).

The OpenPortability project involves:

  • Data collection for data portability between social networks
  • Data collection for creating a snapshot of X network's social structure
  • Data collection for creating snapshots of alternative networks' social structures
  • Data portability
  • Data processing and analysis

II. Data Collection, Recipients, and Retention

Data collected directly from individuals and processed are:

  • Digital identifiers on social networks (username ID)
  • Social network profile names
  • Email addresses

Bluesky's personal data protection policy can be found at: https://bsky.social/about/support/privacy-policy

Mastodon's personal data protection policy can be accessed at https://joinmastodon.org/servers

III. Security Measures

To ensure data confidentiality and protection, measures are taken in accordance with the State's information systems security policy, applied to CNRS. Data is hosted in France on CNRS servers.

IV. Exercise of Your Rights

You can access and obtain a copy of your data, object to the processing of this data, or have it rectified. You also have the right to limit the processing of your data. You can exercise these rights by contacting the data controller at the Complex Systems Institute-Paris Ile de France, located at 113 rue Nationale 75013 Paris, or through the contact form available at https://openportability.org/

You can also contact the CNRS Data Protection Officer (DPO) at: CNRS - Data Protection Service, 2 rue Jean Zay, 54519 Vandoeuvre-l√®s-Nancy - dpd.demandes@cnrs.fr.

If you believe your Information Technology and Civil Liberties rights are not being respected, you can file a complaint online with the CNIL, 3 Place de Fontenoy, TSA 80715 ‚Äì 75334 Paris Cedex 07 (https://www.cnil.fr/).

step1.title: Explore the Social Graph
step1.description: Navigate through 650,000+ Twitter/X accounts visualized by their connections. Each point represents an account, colored by community.
step1.controls:
Scroll = Zoom
Click + Drag = Pan
Click = Select

step2.title: Three View Modes
step2.description: Switch between Discover (explore all), Following (your subscriptions), and Followers (your followers). Your personal network is highlighted when you select a mode.

step3.title: Lasso Selection
step3.description: Draw a selection around accounts to discover who they are. Perfect for exploring communities!
step3.controls:
Click the Lasso tool in the toolbar
Draw around accounts
Stats appear in the panel

step4.title: Reconnect Panel
step4.description: The right panel shows accounts you can reconnect with on Bluesky and Mastodon. Select accounts and click 'Reconnect' to follow them on your new platforms.
